pros:
Great colleagues who turned into friends, very relaxed, friendly office environment.

Excellent work life balance, the best at any job I have had. Fantastic amount of holiday and was always given time off for any overtime, although I think this varies per department. 

The actual tasks given were very easy, not a stressful job. I felt I was going above and beyond every day. 

Good brand to have on your CV. Lovely office location opposite Regents Park.
cons:
This is not a place to stay and progress your career, management recognised fantastic talent but there is really very little power for them to promote or fast-track employees that are going above and beyond. This leads to high turn-over, the bright sparks move on to bigger and better careers, leaving behind those that are happy to coast along. 

Not the best pay. I probably would’ve stayed for longer had the pay been better. 

Poor managers and senior managers in my department that lacked any knowledge or actual skills on how to lead a team. Many were only in their role due to tenure and very opposed to new processes or ways of thinking, which is crucial for innovation. A few managers created friction and unhappiness in the workplace. 

Join this company if you are fresh out of uni, or looking to coast along.

pros:
Location

Multicultural
Holiday package
Facilities

cons:
Pay - Way lower than the market despite senior management trying to convince us otherwise. An assistant is a grade 2 which is truly not representative of the work and skill. Title is misleading to the type of work done specially in Subject areas where faculty don't value the role and misuse it. LBS has to decide if this is an admin role or a personal assistant role (which are different profiles), then redefine the job spec, the grade and the pay. 
Middle Management - More precisely in subject areas: Not always fully supportive of their team specially if they have been there a long time. They feed the highly hierarchical culture, they let faculty get away with a lot of unacceptable things. They don't support increasing the value and recognition of the role. The only way to resolution is out hence the high turnover rate. It's a shame as there's a potential for a healthier and more progressive culture. 
L&D has improved but if you are grade 2, well you can't access a lot of things or argue for a particular learning interest. Another shame.

pros:
•  Beautiful Regents Park close by
•  Many world class academics
•  Staff access to free gym, pool and library
•  Weekly free drinks; good pub attached to premises offering discounts to staff
cons:
•  Sterile campus and sterile location. Poor catering services.
•  Extremely high staff turnover as good people often quickly leave
•  Staff treated like third class citizens compared to the academics and pay for staff is low
•  Academics dramatically overpaid and act accordingly. Many have little interest in the UK and spend most of their time (and the school's money) travelling business class to the US.
•  Crumbling IT systems
•  Hugely conservative and bureaucratic
•  Severely autocratic and bullying culture across several departments.
•  Some inspiring and forward-thinking managers who have fresh ideas are on the way up - but can only imagine change once the old guard leave (the lifers who have never worked anywhere else), as they are blocking the way
•  Arrogant: feel themselves outside the UK HE system but defensive about not being a US business school
•  Muddled twice-yearly performance reviews for staff. Bizarre new requirement for staff (but not academics) to be rated (pay-linked) according to how their behaviours reflect the institution's vision.
•  Non existent in-house professional development (for staff) and no budget for external training
•  Difficult to recommend

review_title: Interesting work environment, great people and very flexible
pros:
Very international outlook in terms of students, staff etc.- it is the most diverse place I've ever worked and you are surrounded by interesting people. In my department the people are very friendly and supportive and the culture is hardworking but relaxed. Very flexible in terms of working hours, working from home, support if you have a family or other commitments. The work is interesting with opportunities to travel for some and there are a number of staff events throughout the year.
On-site gym and pool, good annual leave (28 days plus 3 days at Christmas and bank holidays). Great Dean who is well liked and approachable.
cons: Being a fairly small organisation the lack of career progression can be a big issue and leads to high turnover in some departments. There are few career development opportunities internally, although they are supportive for funding some external learning. Decision making can be slow.

pros: Some great students on the full time MBA programme.  Subsidised cafes and bedroom accommodation on site - the latter especially useful when you work late if you have a long commute
cons: Low remuneration, patchy senior management team, debatable leadership and strategy, lack of personal development opportunities.  Managers devolve everything really important and spend much of their time agonising over trivia. Role of admissions in the School's success is not fully understood.  Support services in finance, HR and IT are all very second rate, as is much of the office accommodation.  Remuneration figures quoted in adverts are before deductions for compulsory pension contributions - tax return time is always a stunning surprise when I see how little I've actually received through the year.  Watch out for other misleading recruiting messages too - for instance around personal development and career potential - both non-existent, in Careers Department at least.

pros: Faculty are brilliant and some of the best minds in academia.
cons: The school is living in the 1970's with regards to its infrastructure; IT, Marketing and Sales. The management culture is highly political and those in management roles on the staff side of the business are mediocre in talent and often unprofessional. Managers do not show confidence to empower their staff and regularly undermine their work, second guess decisions and effectively there are too many management levels with individuals who want to "manage" but don't really add any value.   One of the school's "values" is transparency which is a complete falsehood. Decisions are made via backroom intrigue and political manipulating.
